subject: Learning
title: Ebbinghaus and the Forgetting Curve
description: A short lesson to help you apply Ebbinghaus and the Forgetting Curve.

hook.text: In 1885, a German psychologist memorized nonsense syllables and tracked how fast he forgot them. The results still hold.

buildup.text: Hermann Ebbinghaus discovered that memory decays exponentiallyâ€”you lose most of what you learn within hours.

discovery.text: Within 24 hours, roughly 70% of new information is forgotten without reinforcement.

twist.text: But each review flattens the curve. After enough spaced reviews, memories can last years or even decades.

climax.text: Ebbinghaus proved that forgetting is predictableâ€”and that makes it preventable with the right schedule.

punchline.text: Forgetting is natural. Fighting it strategically is what makes learning stick.

quiz.question: What did Ebbinghaus discover about memory?
options: Memory decays exponentially but spaced reviews can flatten the forgetting curve
Memory never decays once information is learned
All memories fade at the same constant rate
